title: There are no ushers on Mastodon
summary: TL;DR: There are no ushers on Mastodon. There's no one paid to show you to your seat, no one whose job it is to ease you into comfort and remove friction.

title: Twitter, or social cowardice as a service
summary: TL;DR: Yeah, yeah, I'm navel gazing about Twitter over here.

title: My summer spent avoiding a writing habit
Writing Habit Recap No. 3
summary: TL;DR:  I'd meant to do these recap posts every week. But, oops: it's been a month since the last one. Now that I sit down to write this, though, I think I've done more than I thought.

title: Writing Habit Recap No. 2
summary: TL;DR:  I've gotten through over a month of writing posted here. I thought it might be worth reflecting and recapping again.

title: Writing Habit Recap No. 1
summary: TL;DR: I've gotten through twenty days of writing posted here. I thought it might be worth recapping the last few things I managed to post.

title: Building a New Creative Writing Habit
summary: TL;DR: I'm trying to build a new creative writing habit. The immediate form that this has taken is a goal of writing 300 words of fiction per day that I post to my blog. I've been using 3-card spreads from a Tarot deck to supply writing prompts. I'm hoping I keep it up.

title: Writing while burnt out
summary: TL;DR: I'm trying to build a daily creative writing habit. This post is the result of an exercise toward that end. It's probably an awful first draft of a little flash fiction scene, unless I've tried something especially weird or decided to write something meta. Let me know what you think!

title: How to build your own Easy-Blog Oven
summary: TL;DR: I wanted to write more about building my Easy-Blog Oven. I mainly glued together things I already knew, but I think I learned some things and had some surprises anyway.

title: Easy-Blog Oven
summary: TL;DR: I made a new static site generator for my blog. It's not very clever. I've been calling it my "Easy-Blog Oven" and it seems to be working well so far.

title: Heartbroken
summary: TL;DR: My heart is broken. Less shitposting. More thinking. Hopefully something productive, soon.

title: Continual Blogployment
summary: Ever since I switched this blog over to a Gulp-based toolchain - holy crap, 2 years ago - I had a TODO to wire this thing up for continual deployment. Well, today I finally did it.

title: Toot = Tiny Outburst of Text
summary:
I've been toying with something Twitterish lately, and thought I needed a
different word to describe the central social object. So, I started using
toot, which means "tiny outburst of text". Of course, I started by
making fart jokes to myself before that expansion appeared in my head. But, I
think it's fun.

title: What were all those bullets for?
summary:
Did you see that thing I just posted? Weird. Back when I used Dave
Winer's OPML Editor, I used to have a daily habit of opening a
new outline and popping over to it throughout the day to collect random
thoughts.

title: Static blog generation with Gulp and S3
summary:
I've long agreed that many sites, like blogs, are better baked than
fried. It makes for web hosting that's cheaper to run and simpler to
maintain. I've also often thought that using a database can be an
anti-pattern for managing content. But, what I've also found is
that baked sites often yield a poor writing environment. That said, I think
I'm going to give it another try, because I think I might have found a new
approach that works for me.

title: tootr: microblogging app, hosting not included
author: lmorchard
summary: In my last two posts, I wrote about how I’ve been thinking about building yet another microblogging tool and how I think it might be interesting to separate web publishing apps from web hosting. Well, I started tinkering, and I’ve got a rough prototype working.

title: Separating publishing from hosting on the web
author: lmorchard
summary:
Social media like Twitter and Facebook combine web publishing and hosting. You can’t run different software, and you can’t move your stuff. So, if you’re unhappy, your choices are a) deal with it or b) abandon your stuff and your friends. Those are pretty rough options.
But, what if you could move your stuff? And what if you could switch apps?

title: Microblogging like it’s 2002
author: lmorchard
summary: Every year or so, I (re)join the ranks of hackers who decide they’d like to try building a microblogging tool. It’s sometimes after Twitter or Facebook does something cruddy to remind me that I’m the product. Sometimes, it’s when jerks have the run of the place and no one can do anything about it. Often these things are highly correlated.

title: Social novelty filtering (or Google Reader, R.I.P.)
author: lmorchard
summary: Wherein I muse about Google Reader past, and what it might have been. And, wherein I describe what I hope springs up in the aftermath of its closing.

title: And just to make my more than twitter…
author: lmorchard

title: Blogging Like a Blogger
author: lmorchard
excerpt: So, I read about Blogging Like a Hacker a few years ago. It sounded like a neat idea. Finally, after much procrastination, I switched to Jekyll and Disqus for blogging and comments a little over a year ago. Well, guess what? Though the process was novel, I didn't blog with any more frequency than I have over the past couple of years.

title: The Readerpocalypse, or Occupy Google Reader
Using Tinderbox to write articles for the web
Pondering the cobwebs
summary:
It's plain to see that I've not been a blogger for a long time.
This place is a long-neglected ghost town that sees a begrudged entry every few months, when I happen to remember it still exists and I feel guilty for not feeding it with content. What I've yet to figure out is if the cause is a matter of motivation, publishing tools, audience, or writing topics.
Behold as I ramble on for many tens of words pondering the cobwebs here at 0xDECAFBAD.
